Award.AwardTitle: Interest Rate Modeling at the Zero Lower Bound: Applications of Diffusions with Sticky Boundaries
Award.AbstractNarration:
Short-term interest rates in the U.S., the Euro zone, and Japan have been near zero since the global financial crisis of 2008, due to the monetary policy responses by the central banks to the financial crisis and the recession that followed. Conventional mathematical models of interest rates break down when the short term interest rate is at the zero lower bound (ZLB). This project develops and investigates a novel class of mathematical models of interest rates with the zero lower bound based on the mathematics of diffusion processes with sticky boundaries. The anticipated impact of the project is in applications in the financial industry to the pricing and hedging of interest-rate-sensitive financial instruments, to managing interest rate risk, to fixed income portfolio construction, and in central banking to aid in conducting monetary policy, as well as in training of doctoral students in financial mathematics and engineering.

The class of diffusions with sticky boundaries is well suited to the challenge of modeling the ZLB, as it naturally supplies a model with two distinct economic regimes -- the process away from the boundary and the process on the boundary. This project develops analytical and computational tools to work with diffusions with sticky boundaries, including computational methods specifically tailored for this class of stochastic processes, and applies them to develop and empirically test interest rate models. The intellectual merit of this project is in the development of a novel class of interest rate models based on diffusions with sticky boundaries, and in the associated analytical and computational methods to solve stochastic differential equations with sticky boundaries and partial differential equations with Wentzell boundary conditions. Graduate students are included in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Short-term interest rates in advanced economies, including the U.S., the Euro zone and Japan, have been near zero since the global financial crisis of 2008 due to the monetary policy responses by the central banks to the financial crisis and the recession that followed.  While the U.S. short-term interest rate has been positive over the past several years, rates in the Euro zone and Japan are still near zero. Conventional mathematical models of interest rates break down when the short term interest rate is at the zero lower bound. Modeling interest rates with the zero lower bound is a challenging and important practical problem for central banks and the financial services industry.

This project developed new mathematical models of interest rates with the zero lower bound, analytical and computational tools to solve these models numerically, and statistical procedures to estimate these models from empirical data on historical interest rate data.

The main class of mathematical models currently in use by central banks and in the financial services industry to describe interest rates with the zero lower bound are the so-called shadow rate models. These models feature a shadow interest rate that is allowed to become negative and is unbounded from below. The nominal short term interest rate is described as the positive part function of the shadow rate. These models do not admit analytical solutions when the dimension of the model is greater than one. Two-dimensional models are typically solved via finite-difference schemes to solve the associated partial differential equation.

For three-dimensional shadow rate models the differential equation is too challenging to solve by finite differences. Analytical approximations are currently in use to approximate solutions for three-dimensional shadow rate models. These approximations can suffer from sizable approximation errors for certain parameter combinations. This project developed an improved analytical approximation for three-dimensional shadow interest rate models that remedies this issue.

Furthremore, this project developed a new and more general class of interest rate models that have additional modeling flexibility due to separate parameters governing the dynamics of the yield curve when the short term interest rate is sitting at the boundary at zero. These models are based on a class of stochastic differential equations with so-called sticky boundaries.

The results of this project are described in four scientific papers. One doctoral student successfully defended his Ph.D. dissertation based on the research supported by this project. The second doctoral student involved in this project is currently in his 4th year in the Ph.D. program.
